questions.question: When is World AIDS day observed?
What are the most common modes of transmission of HIV in India in descending order?
questions.explanation: The most common mode of transmission of HIV in India is heterosexual transmission, followedby transplacental and homosexual contact, respectively.The common modes of transmission of HIV are:• Heterosexual (83.7%)•Injecting drug users (5.6%)Transplacental transmission (3.8%)• Homosexual (2.5%)• Blood and blood products (0.8%)• Unknown (3.6%)309The highest risk of transmission is seen in homosexuals due to the increased risk of abrasionsduring anal sex.

questions.question: Health care workers will require post-exposure prophylaxis after exposure to which of thefollowing body fluids of an HIV patient?
questions.explanation: Health care workers exposed to the menstrual blood of an HIV-positive patient will requirepost-exposure prophylaxis. The risk of transmission of HIV during vaginal intercourse is higherwhen the woman is menstruating.Tears, non-blood-stained saliva, urine, and sweat do not pose a significant risk. Exposure to thesefluids does not require post-exposure prophylaxis.

questions.question: As per WHO staging of HIV, which of the following HIV-positive patients cannot be classifiedas stage IV?

options.A: A 29-year-old man diagnosed with cerebral toxoplasmosis
options.B: A 56-year-old woman with significant weight loss and muscle wasting300
options.C: A 43-year-old lady being treated for Pneumocystis pneumonia

questions.explanation: Oral candidiasis is seen in stage 3, not stage 4 of HIV.The following conditions are included in the WHO stage IV of HIV:• HIV wasting syndrome (Slim disease)• HIV encephalopathy• HIV-associated nephropathy or cardiomyopathy• Infections:••Pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia (previously known as Pneumocystis carinii)Chronic herpes simplex infection, cytomegalovirus disease.Oesophageal/ tracheal candidiasis• Extrapulmonary TB or disseminated M. avium infection• CNS toxoplasmosis••Extrapulmonary cryptococcosisChronic cryptosporidiosis or isosporiasis• Disseminated fungal infections (histoplasmosis, coccidioidomycosis)• Recurrent severe bacterial pneumonia or septicemia• Atypical disseminated leishmaniasis• Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy•Neoplasms:•Kaposi sarcoma• Lymphoma (cerebral or B cell non-Hodgkin)• Invasive cervical carcinoma310

questions.question: A 45-year man with a high-risk sexual history now presents with prolonged fever for the past1.5 months. On examination, the following finding is noted. Which one of the followingadditional features is required to diagnose this patient with AIDS?
questions.explanation: This clinical scenario is suspicious for HIV infection. As per the WHO definition, the presenceof chronic diarrhea > 1 month is needed to diagnose this patient with AIDS.The WHO clinical definition is used for AIDS surveillance in the clinical setting. Patients > 12years of age are said to have AIDS if they have at least 2 major and 1 minor signs, provided otherclinically similar conditions are be ruled out.Major signs:•• Weight loss ≥ 10% of body weight•Chronic diarrhea > 1 month•Prolonged fever for > 1 month (intermittent or constant)Minor signs:• A persistent cough > 1 month•Generalized pruritic dermatitis••History of herpes zosterOropharyngeal candidiasis• Chronic progressive or disseminated herpes simplex infection• Generalized lymphadenopathyFor surveillance purposes, the presence of either of the following is also considered sufficient todiagnose AIDS:• Generalized Kaposi's sarcoma•• Cryptococcal meningitis

questions.question: Which of the following is incorrect regarding the epidemiology of HIV?

options.A: HIV infected infants and children do not progress rapidly to AIDS
options.B: Seminal secretions are more infectious than vaginal secretion
options.C: People are infectious during the window period
options.D: HIV prevalence has not exceeded 5% in any subpopulation

questions.explanation: Infants and children infected with HIV progress rapidly to AIDS.Semen is more infectious than vaginal or cervical fluids as it has a higher concentration of HIV.HIV-infected patients are highly infectious during:• Window period (very early stages before antibody production)•• Advanced stages of infection (due to higher levels of viremia)HIV prevalence has consistently remained < 5% in all defined subpopulations.

questions.question: 301In individuals exposed to HIV, within how many hours should prophylaxis be initiated?
questions.explanation: Post-exposure prophylaxis for HIV should ideally be initiated within 72 hours. It is recommendedthat it be started as even as early as < 2 hours.311

questions.question: A nurse sustained a needle stick injury while sampling the blood of a patient who isHIV-positive. Which of the following is incorrect?

options.A: Washing hands with soap and water
options.C: Measure baseline viral markers of health care worker immediately

questions.explanation: Triple therapy (tenofovir 300mg + lamivudine 300mg + dolutegravir 50mg) is recommended forHIV post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP), not monotherapy.Steps to be undertaken after a needlestick injury are:•Wash the wound and skin with water and soap. Do not scrub and avoid antiseptics.• Assess exposed individual:•Check baseline viral markers•Monitor for acute seroconversion illness within 3-6 weeks after exposure• If testing is positive, refer to ART center• Assess exposure source and determine the risk of transmission•Counseling and support••• Initiate PEP at the earliest - preferably < 2 hours and ideally < 72 hours28-day prescription with drug information• HIV test at 3 months after exposure

questions.question: A resident doctor sustained a needlestick injury while sampling blood of a patient who is HIVpositive. A decision is taken to offer him post-exposure prophylaxis. Which one of thefollowing would be the best recommendation?
questions.explanation: Triple therapy with tenofovir 300mg, lamivudine 300mg, and dolutegravir 50mg for 4 weeks isrecommended for HIV post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP).Steps to be undertaken after a needlestick injury are:•Wash the wound and skin with water and soap. Do not scrub and avoid antiseptics.• Assess exposed individual:•Check baseline viral markers•Monitor for acute seroconversion illness within 3-6 weeks after exposure• If testing is positive, refer to ART center• Assess exposure source and determine the risk of transmission•Counseling and support•• Initiate PEP at the earliest - preferably < 2 hours and ideally < 72 hours28-day prescription with drug information• HIV test at 3 months after exposure312

questions.question: Which of the following HIV-infected patients would you start on cotrimoxazole prophylaxis?

options.A: A 24-year-old pregnant woman with WHO stage 2 disease.
options.B: A 47-year-old man in a malaria-endemic area with WHO stage 1 disease
options.C: A 2-week-old HIV-exposed infant who is being exclusively breastfed
options.D: A 7-year-old girl with a CD4 count of 400 cells/cubic mm302

questions.explanation: All HIV infected adults and children in malaria-endemic areas should be given cotrimoxazoleprophylaxis regardless of CD4 count or WHO clinical stage.Cotrimoxazole is also indicated in areas with a low prevalence of malaria as shown below:Age groupHIV-exposed infants > 4-6 wIndicationAll infantseeks of ageChildren < 5 yearsAll childrenChildren >5 yearsAdults and pregnant womenHIV and TB coinfectionCD4 count <350 and/or WHO stage 3/4CD4 count <350 and/or WHO stage 3/4All patientsWhen to discontinueAfter HIV infection has beenruled outAt 5 years in areas with low prevalence of malaria(In highprevalence areas, continue til1 adulthood)When CD4 > 350 and they have been on ART > 6 monthsWhen CD4 count is rising and viral load is decreasing

questions.question: A 45-year-old man with HIV is being screened for symptoms of TB. He reports no cough,fever, night sweats, or weight loss. What is the next step in management?

options.A: Start 5 mg/kg/day Isoniazid daily for 9 months
options.B: Prophylaxis does not need to be started
options.D: Start weekly dose of rifapentine + isoniazid for 3 months

questions.explanation: The next step in management in this patient is to provide tuberculosis preventive therapy (TPT)with rifapentine+ isoniazid weekly for 3 months.According to the NTEP guidelines, TPT is indicated for the following groups:IGRA - interferon-gamma release assay; TST - tuberculin skin test; ATT - antituberculous therapyTPT is contraindicated under the following conditions:• Active TB•Active hepatitis• Peripheral neuropathy• Regular and heavy alcohol consumptionRisk groupPeople living with HIVHousehold contacts (HHC) ofpulmonary TB patients < 5yearsCriteriaNegative 4 symptom test - start TPT after ruling out TBPatients with active TB - start TPT after completion of the ATT regimenStart TPT after ruling out active TB313Risk groupHousehold contacts of pulmonary TB patients ≥ 5 yearsOther risk groups: Children/adults on immunosuppressive therapyPatients on anti-TNF treatmentPatients on dialysis orpost-transplantationPatientswith silicosisCriteriaFirst rule out active TBStartTPT ifIGRA or TSTispositivewith a normal chest x-rayTarget PopulationPeople living with HIV (adults and children > 2 years)HHC of pulmonary TB patientsInfants <12 months of age and Children <2years of age with HIVTreatment option3-month weekly Isoniazid (300 mg) and Rifapentine (300mg) in persons older than 2years6-months daily isoniazid (6H): 10 mg/kg/day

questions.question: Which of the following is true about the 2025 targets of the Global AIDS Strategy for 2021 to2026?
questions.explanation: 95%, not 75% of HIV-exposed children are tested by 2 months of age and after stoppingbreastfeeding according to the 2025 targets.Global AIDS Strategy 2021-2026 has the following targets for the year 2025:Target %95% of90% ofTarget populationPeople at risk of HIV infectionWomen of reproductive agePregnant and breastfeedingwomen with HIVHIV-exposed childrenPeople living with HIVPeople living with HIV and people at riskTarget interventionAccess to effectivepreventionoptionsHave their HIV, sexual, reproductivehealth service needsmetSuppressedviral loadsTested by 2 months of age and again after stopping breastfeedingPreventive treatment forTBLinked to services for overallhealth and wellbeing including:Communicable and non-communicable diseasesSexual healthGender-based violenceMental health and substance abuse314Target %75% of95-95-95testing and treatment targets to be achieved within all subpopulations, age groups, and geographic settings,including children living with HIV.Target populationAll children living with HIVTarget interventionSuppressedviral loadsby 2023 (interim target)

questions.question: A 29-year-old man comes to you with complaints of painful swelling in his right groin, asshown below. He gives a history of 3-4 painless ulcers over his penis 4 weeks ago that hadresolved on its own. What is the likely causative organism?303
questions.explanation: This clinical scenario and image showing the groove sign of Greenblatt are suggestiveof lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV). The causative organism is Chlamydia trachomatis.LGV commonly presents with multiple small, painless ulcers on the genitalia that are oftenunrecognized and resolve spontaneously. This is followed by painful lymphadenopathy and buboformation after 4-6 weeks. If left untreated, it can lead to extensive lymphatic damage,elephantiasis, and deformity of the genitalia.The treatment of choice is doxycycline.

questions.question: Match the following conditions with their causative agents:
questions.explanation: The causative organisms of the given conditions are as follows:India is the first country in the world to be officially acknowledged as being yaws-free. The WHOdeclared India free of yaws on 5th May 2016.ConditionPintaLymphogranuloma venereumSYawsOrganismTreponema carateumChlamydia trachomatiGranuloma inguinaleSTreponema pertenueKlebsiella granulomati

questions.question: Match the following STDs with their respective incubation periods:
questions.explanation: The incubation periods of various STDs are as follows:315STDIncubation periodSyphilis10-90 daysChlamydia7-21 dayssisDonovano3-40 dayssisChancroid2-3 days

questions.question: Which of the following is not a part of case detection in STDs?
questions.explanation: Notification is not part of the case detection strategy for STDs. Case detection in STDs includesthe following:• Screening• Contact tracing•⚫ Cluster testing

questions.question: A 32-year-old man is diagnosed with syphilis. On probing, he gives you the information ofother people in the same sociosexual environment as him. You then refer all these people fortesting. What is this method of case detection?304
questions.explanation: This method of case detection is known as cluster testing.The methods employed in case detection of STDs are:•-Screening testing of apparently healthy volunteers from the general population for earlydetection of disease.Contact tracing - technique by which the sexual partners of diagnosed patients are identified,located, investigated, and treated•• Cluster testing - patients are asked to name other persons who move in the same socio-sexualenvironment, who are then tested

questions.question: A 29-year-old man with urethral discharge is treated with the grey kit. This treatment iseffective for the control of which of the following organisms?
questions.explanation: The grey kit is effective for the treatment of infections caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae andChlamydia trachomatis.

questions.question: Which of the following is false about the epidemiology of leprosy?

options.A: Increased prevalence in childhood indicates that the disease is active and spreading.
options.B: Multibacillary cases are the most infectious in the community
options.C: Bacterial load is highest in patients with tuberculoid leprosy
options.D: Seldom may be transmitted by insect vectors

questions.explanation: The bacterial load is highest in patients with lepromatous leprosy. 1 gram of leproma contains asmany as 2-7 billion bacilli.316Multibacillary cases (lepromatous and borderline lepromatous) are the most important source ofinfection in the community. Infection can occur at any age. In general, cases rise to a peakbetween 10-20 years of age and then fall. In endemic areas, the disease is acquired commonlyduring childhood. A high prevalence in this age group indicates that the disease is active andspreading.The organism may also be transmitted by insect vectors or by tattooing needles. However, this isnot clinically significant.

questions.question: Elimination of leprosy in India is defined as the prevalence of:
questions.explanation: Elimination of leprosy in India is defined as a prevalence of < 1 per 10,000.

questions.question: What is the prevalence of leprosy in India per 10,000?305
questions.explanation: The prevalence of leprosy in India is 0.41 per 10,000 as of March 2021.

questions.question: The Ridley Jopling classification for leprosy uses which of the following parameters?
questions.explanation: The Ridley Jopling classification uses clinical, bacteriological, immunological, and histologicalparameters.

questions.question: A pathologist is studying the split skin smears taken from 4 sites of a leprosy patient. Thefollowing findings are noted in the samples. What is the bacteriological index?
questions.explanation: The bacteriological index (BI) of the given samples is 3.5According to Ridley's logarithmic scale,• 10 bacilli out of 100 oil immersion fields indicate an index of 1+> 1000 bacilli out of average fields imply an index of 6+The bacteriological index is calculated by adding the index from each site examined and dividingthe total by the number of sites examined.Hence, BI = (1+1+6+6) / 4BI = 14/4BI = 3.5

questions.question: The lepromin test was performed on a patient with suspected leprosy. When will you ask himto come back for interpretation of the test results?
questions.explanation: 317The patient should be asked to come back after 48 hours and on the 21st day for interpretation ofthe test results.The lepromin test is a skin test for delayed hypersensitivity and is the only method to studyimmunity in leprosy patients. It is performed by injecting 0.1ml of leprominreagent intradermally into the inner aspect of the forearm. The following 2 reactions are observed:Early reaction of FernandezDevelops in 24-48 hoursRemains for 3-5 daysPoorly defined erythema andinduration. Carries less significanceLate reaction of MitsudaStarts at 7-10 days, peaks at3-4 weeks (read on day 21)Gradually subsides over the next few weeksConsidered positive if there is a nodule > 5 mm in diameter

questions.question: Which of the following is false about the lepromin test?306

options.A: It is negative in most children in the first 4 months of life
options.B: It can be used as a diagnostic test
options.C: It is used to classify leprosy cases
options.D: False positive may be seen in those who underwent BCG vacination

questions.explanation: The lepromin test is not a diagnostic test. It is only used to assess the immune status, classify thecases, and estimate the prognosis.The two main drawbacks of this test are:•False-positive results in those who received BCG vaccination• False-negative results in lepromatous and borderline lepromatous cases

questions.question: A group of public health workers is trying to identify trachoma cases at an ophthalmologycamp. Which of the following is the best index to assess for trachoma inflammation?

options.A: Follicles on the upper tarsal conjuctiva
options.D: Vascular pannus at the superior limbus

questions.explanation: In epidemiological studies, the upper tarsal conjunctiva is the best index of trachomatousinflammation in the eye.For the purpose of diagnosis, any 2 of the following diagnostic criteria must be present:• Follicles on the upper tarsal conjunctiva•• Limbal follicles and Herbert's pitsTypical conjunctival scarring (trichiasis and entropion)• Vascular pannus, most marked at the superior limbusThe following image shows follicles on the upper tarsal conjunctiva seen in trachomatousinflammation.3188

questions.question: Which of the following is true about the organisms causing trachoma?

options.A: Morax- Axenfeld bacillus is the most widespread
options.B: Gonococcus is the most dangerous organism contributing to the disease process
options.C: Koch-Weeks bacillus is the most innocuous
options.D: C. trachomatis type D commonly causes permanent visual damage

questions.explanation: Gonococcus is the most dangerous organism contributing to the disease process in trachoma.Classic endemic trachoma is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis types A, B, C. Other pathogenicorganisms that contribute to the disease process are:• Morax-Axenfeld diplobacillus - most innocuous⚫ Kochs-Weeks bacillus - most widespread•• Gonococcus most dangerous-The types D-K of C. trachomatis are sexually transmitted and cause inclusion conjunctivitis. Itrarely causes permanent vision loss.

questions.question: The elimination of neonatal tetanus is defined as:
questions.explanation: The elimination of neonatal tetanus is defined as <1 case per 1000 live births in everydistrict. Maternal and neonatal tetanus (MNT) was eliminated in India in 2015.Since July 2018, TT vaccines have been replaced by the Td vaccine for dual protection.

questions.question: Which of the following diseases is called the 8th day disease?307
questions.explanation: Neonatal tetanus is known as the 8th-day disease. This is because the clinical features are oftenseen after the 7th day after birth due to infection of the umbilical cord.Option A: Trench fever is also called the 5-day fever.319Option B: Pertussis is called the 100-day cough.Option D: Scarlet fever is also known as the 2nd disease.

questions.question: A 13-year-old girl is brought to the casualty a few hours after being injured by a rusty knife.According to her parents, her course of tetanus vaccination was completed 7 years ago. Whatis the next best step in management?

options.D: Human tetanus immunoglobulin and single dose of toxoid

questions.explanation: This clinical scenario is suggestive of a contaminated wound in a patient who received completeimmunization against tetanus 7 years ago. She comes under category B of tetanus immunizationand must be given a single dose of tetanus toxoid alone.The WHO recommends a 3-dose primary vaccination series with tetanus-diphtheria-containingvaccine followed by 3 booster doses. Ideally, there should be at least 4 years between boosterdoses.320
